introPages.title: The function of pronouns
introPages.body:
Pronouns replace or refer to nouns. They avoid repetition and make sentences flow: John left. He said he would return.

In Part 2, gaps often need: personal pronouns (it, they, them), demonstratives (this, that, these, those), or there for existence: There are many reasons.

Special use: it as a dummy subject when the real subject is later: It is important to book early. / It seems that …

introPages.title: Relative pronouns
introPages.body:
Relative pronouns introduce a clause that describes a noun. They refer back to that noun (the antecedent).

Things: which, that – The book which I read / The book that I read

People: who, that – The person who called / The person that called

Places: where – the town where I grew up

Possession: whose – the woman whose car was stolen

Object (formal): whom – the person whom we met

introPages.title: Defining and non-defining clauses
introPages.body:
Defining (restrictive) – essential to identify the noun: The book that I lent you. No comma before the relative pronoun. That can replace which or who.

Non-defining (non-restrictive) – extra information: This book, which I bought yesterday, is excellent. Comma before (and after) the clause. Use which or who – not that.

introPages.title: Common mistake: misuse of 'what'
introPages.body:
What is not a relative pronoun that refers back to a noun. It does not replace which or that when describing a noun.

❌ The thing what I meant → ✓ The thing that/which I meant

❌ The person what came → ✓ The person who/that came

❌ All what we need → ✓ All (that) we need or What we need

What is correct when it stands alone and means “the thing(s) that”: What I meant was … / I know what you mean. Here there is no noun before what.

introPages.title: Other common mistakes
introPages.body:
It vs there: It = dummy subject or refers to something specific. There = existence: There are many reasons (not It are). It is important (not There is important).

Which vs who: which for things, who for people. The team which/that won (team as unit) or The people who won.

Whose = belonging to (people or things): the house whose roof was damaged.

mcQuiz.question: In ___ are many reasons for this, which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: There + be expresses existence. 'There are many reasons.'

mcQuiz.question: In The book ___ I lent you is on the table, which relative pronoun fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Book is a thing – use which or that. Never what.

mcQuiz.question: In The person ___ called left a message, which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Person = people – use who or that. Never what.

mcQuiz.question: Is The thing what I said correct?
mcQuiz.explanation: What cannot refer back to a noun. Use 'the thing that/which I said'.

mcQuiz.question: In ___ is important to arrive early, which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: It as dummy subject for the real subject (to arrive early).

mcQuiz.question: In I know ___ you mean (no noun before the gap), which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: What = the thing(s) that. Here it stands alone – correct.

mcQuiz.question: In All ___ we need is time, which fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: After 'all', use that (or omit it). 'All what' is wrong.

shortQuestions.question: The thing what I meant was clear.
accepted: the thing that i meant was clear
the thing which i meant was clear
shortQuestions.explanation: What cannot refer back to 'thing'. Use which/that, or use 'What I meant' (what stands alone).

shortQuestions.question: The person what came was my brother.
accepted: the person who came was my brother
the person that came was my brother
shortQuestions.explanation: What is not used for people. Use who or that.

shortQuestions.question: All what we need is a ticket.
accepted: all we need is a ticket
all that we need is a ticket
what we need is a ticket
shortQuestions.explanation: After 'all', use that or omit it. Or use 'What we need' (what = the thing that).

shortQuestions.question: Everything what he does is wrong.
accepted: everything that he does is wrong
shortQuestions.explanation: What cannot refer back to 'everything'. Use that or omit. Or 'What he does' (standalone).

shortQuestions.question: The house what we bought needs repairs.
accepted: the house that we bought needs repairs
the house which we bought needs repairs
shortQuestions.explanation: House is a thing – use which or that. Never what.

shortQuestions.question: There is many reasons for this.
accepted: there are many reasons for this
shortQuestions.explanation: 'Reasons' is plural – use There are (not There is).

shortQuestions.question: It are several options available.
shortQuestions.explanation: Existence with plural – use There are. It cannot be used this way.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why is 'what' often misused as a relative pronoun?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: In some languages, one word serves both roles. In English, what = 'the thing(s) that' as a unit, with no antecedent. Which/that/who refer back to a noun. The thing that I meant ✓. The thing what I meant ❌.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When do we use it vs there as a subject?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: It: dummy subject (It is important to...), or referring to something specific (It was raining). There: existence (There are many reasons, There is a problem). Never 'It are' or 'There is important'.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the difference between defining and non-defining relative clauses.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Defining: identifies which one (The book that I lent you – essential). No comma. That can replace which/who. Non-defining: extra info (This book, which I bought yesterday, is excellent). Commas. Use which/who, not that.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three sentences where what is correct.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. What I meant was clear. / I know what you mean. / What we need is time. In each case, what stands alone and means 'the thing(s) that'.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When might you use whose for things (not just people)?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Whose can refer to things when we need possession: the house whose roof was damaged, the company whose profits fell. It avoids awkward 'of which' constructions.
